meta.notes: Resonance observations documented separately in W2 memorizer's journal

generation.prompt_text: A unified interior illustration of arriving at the Siege of Mirado, viewed as if standing in the doorway of a soldier's tent looking out at the desert encampment before the Tower. In the foreground on the left, a worn leather satchel sits open on the ground, spilling rolled maps and a brass compass with only three directions marked. Beside it in the center foreground, a clay bowl holds dried maize kernels, some scattered on the dusty canvas floor. To the right foreground, iron tent stakes are driven into clod-mud, with frayed rope still attached. In the middle distance rising toward the back, the scene opens to the encampment. On the right side, a cooking fire smolders under a blackened iron pot, steam curling upward. At center back, a siege ladder leans against stacked supply crates, its rungs worn smooth. On the left in the background, a torn regimental banner hangs limp from a pole, its insignia barely visible. Beyond all this, the Tower of Mirado hovers in the distance—steel-gray and luminous, its crown fountain catching light. The color palette draws from Densworld materials: Quarry Ochre and Clod-mud Earth for warm earth tones, Tower Steel Gray for metallic elements, Iron Gall Black for shadows and ink-like details, Desert Maize Yellow for highlights. Cartographic illustration style with clean lines, unified lighting from top-left, deep focus keeping all elements sharp. Aspect ratio 16:9. One continuous scene, not separate panels. Six distinct objects clearly separated by negative space.

objects.text: Nel mezzo del cammin di nostra vita
mi ritrovai per una selva oscura,
ché la diritta via era smarrita.
Ahi quanto a dir qual era è cosa dura
esta selva selvaggia e aspra e forte
che nel pensier rinova la paura!

generation.prompt_text: A unified exterior illustration of Yeller Quarry at dusk, viewed as if standing at the rim looking down into the terraced pit. In the foreground on the left, a heavy leather-bound ledger lies open on a flat stone, its pages water-stained and curling at the edges. Beside it in the center foreground, a pickaxe rests against a wooden ore cart, its iron head catching the last light. To the right foreground, a tin lunch pail sits open, revealing a crust of bread and an apple core. In the middle distance on the right side, a gnarled yeller-oak grows from a crack in the quarry wall, its roots gripping the stone. At center back, a surveyor's tripod stands abandoned on a ledge, brass telescope tilted toward the pit floor. On the left in the background, a coil of hemp rope hangs from an iron spike driven into the rock face. The quarry descends in golden-brown terraces toward the pit floor where Prime Yeller veins catch fading light. Dust hangs in the amber dusk air. The color palette draws from Densworld materials: Quarry Ochre (#B45309) for the stone walls and earth, Knocker-bug Gold (#CA8A04) for the yeller veins and brass fittings, Iron Gall Black (#1F2937) for shadows and the ledger binding, Dead River Silt Gray (#78716C) for the dust and weathered surfaces. Cartographic illustration style with clean lines, unified lighting from top-left, deep focus keeping all elements sharp. Aspect ratio 16:9. One continuous scene, not separate panels. Six distinct objects clearly separated by negative space.

objects.text: Tant' è amara che poco è più morte;
ma per trattar del ben ch'i' vi trovai,
dirò de l'altre cose ch'i' v'ho scorte.
Io non so ben ridir com' i' v'intrai,
tant' era pien di sonno a quel punto
che la verace via abbandonai.

generation.prompt_text: A unified interior illustration of a Capital Archive reading room at dawn, viewed as if standing in the doorway looking across the long chamber toward tall windows. In the foreground on the left, a brass candlestick holder stands on a desk edge, its candle burned to a stub with wax pooled at the base. Beside it in the center foreground, an inkwell sits uncapped next to a scattered pile of official seals, their wax impressions still soft. To the right foreground, a wooden filing cabinet drawer hangs open, documents spilling onto the floor. In the middle distance on the right side, a high-backed reading chair faces away, its leather cracked and worn. At center back, a tall window lets in the first gray light, an iron latch hanging loose. On the left in the background, a wall-mounted gas lamp flickers, its glass shade darkened with soot. Morning light filters through dust motes. The archive stretches into shadow beyond the reading alcoves. The color palette draws from Densworld materials: Iron Gall Black (#1F2937) for the deep wood and shadows, Tower Steel Gray (#9CA3AF) for the morning light and metal fixtures, Quarry Ochre (#B45309) for leather and warm wood tones, Knocker-bug Gold (#CA8A04) for brass fittings and wax seals. Cartographic illustration style with clean lines, unified lighting from top-left, deep focus keeping all elements sharp. Aspect ratio 16:9. One continuous scene, not separate panels. Six distinct objects clearly separated by negative space.

objects.text: Ma poi ch'i' fui al piè d'un colle giunto,
là dove terminava quella valle
che m'avea di paura il cor compunto,
guardai in alto e vidi le sue spalle
vestite già de' raggi del pianeta
che mena dritto altrui per ogne calle.

generation.prompt_text: A unified exterior illustration of the Ferryman's Dock on the Dead River at night, viewed as if standing on the broken concrete landing looking across the dark water. In the foreground on the left, a rusted mooring cleat juts from cracked concrete, its chain trailing into the black water. In the center foreground, a battered tin lantern sits on a coil of wet rope, its flame guttering behind soot-stained glass. To the right foreground, a Gritsmuck Crawler—a palm-sized crustacean with a segmented shell—picks at debris on the dock edge. In the middle distance on the right side, stilted shanty pylons rise from the water, their wood blackened and slick. At center back, the silhouette of the Broken Deadriver Bridge hangs half-collapsed against a starless sky, its central span sagging into the current. On the left in the background, a ferryman's punt is tied to a listing post, its pole laid across empty seats. The Dead River moves slow and dark, reflecting nothing. The air smells of silt and exhaustion. The color palette draws from Densworld materials: Dead River Silt Gray (#78716C) for water and weathered surfaces, Grimslew Scale Black (#030712) for the deepest shadows and water, Iron Gall Black (#1F2937) for rusted metal and wet wood, Quarry Ochre (#B45309) for the lantern flame and rope. Cartographic illustration style with clean lines, unified lighting from the single lantern, deep focus keeping all elements sharp. Aspect ratio 16:9. One continuous scene, not separate panels. Six distinct objects clearly separated by negative space.

objects.text: Allor fu la paura un poco queta,
che nel lago del cor m'era durata
la notte ch'i' passai con tanta pièta.
E come quei che con lena affannata,
uscito fuor del pelago a la riva,
si volge a l'acqua perigliosa e guata,

images.sub_location: Deep cave, Maw Beast attack site (Year 855)

narrative_source.description: Truck's death defending the Boss from Maw Beast; Redmane Expedition disaster

generation.prompt_text: A unified interior illustration of a deep Yeller Quarry cave in Year 855, viewed from the perspective of a survivor looking back toward the attack site. The moment after the Maw Beast struck. In the foreground on the left, Ox kneels in the mud, dragging Truck's body by the collar—Truck's face is turned away, obscured. Ox's rope-calloused hands grip the fabric. In the center foreground, a shattered lantern lies on the cave floor, its oil still burning in a spreading pool, casting wild shadows. To the right foreground, a discarded trapping hook—the Boss's signature tool with red-dyed grip—lies where she dropped it when the creature threw her. In the middle distance on the right side, the Maw Beast's bulk retreats into shadow, its form massive and hunched, visible only as a silhouette of bristled hide and too many limbs. At center back, the cave narrows toward the depths, Prime Yeller veins catching the firelight in golden threads against the black stone. On the left in the background, a figure in a maze-braided red hair—the Boss—lies crumpled against the cave wall, one arm raised as if reaching. The cave smells of blood, oil, and yeller dust. Someone is screaming. The color palette draws from Densworld materials: Grimslew Scale Black (#030712) for the deepest cave shadows, Quarry Ochre (#B45309) for the Yeller veins and firelight, Iron Gall Black (#1F2937) for wet rock and blood, Dead River Silt Gray (#78716C) for mud and exhausted flesh. Cartographic illustration style with clean lines, unified lighting from the burning oil pool, deep focus keeping all elements sharp. Aspect ratio 16:9. One continuous scene, not separate panels. Six distinct objects clearly separated by negative space. No title banners or labels.

objects.text: così l'animo mio, ch'ancor fuggiva,
si volse a retro a rimirar lo passo
che non lasciò già mai persona viva.
Poi ch'èi posato un poco il corpo lasso,
ripresi via per la piaggia diserta,
sì che 'l piè fermo sempre era 'l più basso.

narrative_source.description: Nelphl's terminal observation at the Focal Meadow crater; Bincher witnesses the ending

generation.prompt_text: A unified exterior illustration of the Focal Meadow crater rim at dusk, Year 799, viewed from behind Bincher as she witnesses Nelphl's final moments. In the foreground on the left, Bincher's leather-bound field journal lies open on the grass, her handwriting trailing off mid-sentence. In the center foreground, dried fish wrapped in cloth—her uneaten meal—sits beside the journal, forgotten. To the right foreground, a Metal-Beaked Finch perches on a stone, its distinctive iron-colored beak tilted toward the crater. In the middle distance on the right side, Nelphl kneels at the crater's edge, her loose dark hair falling across her face as she leans forward. At center back, the smooth rim of the Focal Meadow crater curves away, its surface impossibly regular, the depression beyond filled with evening shadow. On the left in the background, Bincher herself stands frozen, one arm raised as if to call out or reach—but it's too late. The meadow grass ripples in a wind that seems to pull toward the crater. The sky is copper and gray. Something is ending. The color palette draws from Densworld materials: Meadow Oxidized Copper (#78350F) for the evening sky and grass shadows, Dead River Silt Gray (#78716C) for the crater rim, Iron Gall Black (#1F2937) for the deepening shadows, Quarry Ochre (#B45309) for the warm light on skin and cloth. Cartographic illustration style with clean lines, unified lighting from the setting sun, deep focus keeping all elements sharp. Aspect ratio 16:9. One continuous scene, not separate panels. Six distinct objects clearly separated by negative space. No title banners or labels.

objects.text: Ed ecco, quasi al cominciar de l'erta,
una lonza leggera e presta molto,
che di pel macolato era coverta;
e non mi si partia dinanzi al volto,
anzi 'mpediva tanto il mio cammino,
ch'i' fui per ritornar più volte vòlto.
